Description: Align proximity activation times with temperature trends to detect when users stand near the fixture waiting for water to reach a comfortable temperature before fully engaging with it.
short rationale: Shows waiting near fixture and warm-up timing tied to routines.

inference: User patience threshold for warm water
Description: Measure how long proximity is sustained before temperature enters the user’s typical comfort range; repeated patterns reveal how long users are willing to wait for warm water before giving up or changing behavior.
short rationale: Reveals tolerance and start-of-use timing.

inference: Idle heating with no user present
Description: Identify periods where temperature rises or remains elevated while there is no proximity activation, indicating water is being heated or maintained hot even though no one is near the fixture.
short rationale: Highlights absence with unnecessary heating; limited identity.

Description: Detect sequences where proximity activation is followed by rapid temperature changes, indicating that users approach, adjust temperature while present, and then settle into a stable comfort range.
short rationale: Captures detailed interaction sequence around use.

Description: Within intervals of continuous proximity, count how often temperature is adjusted up or down; frequent adjustments suggest users struggle to find a comfortable temperature or that the system is thermally unstable near the user.
short rationale: Shows comfort-seeking behavior during sessions.

Description: When proximity patterns suggest smaller/shorter presence (e.g., child-height sensor placement) and temperature trends approach unsafe levels, the system can infer a need for stricter maximum temperature limits while children are present.
short rationale: Infers presence of children and safety context.

Description: Find cases where users trigger proximity once, set a temperature that quickly stabilizes, then exhibit little additional proximity activity; this pattern reflects users who prefer a fixed, stable temperature with minimal ongoing interaction.
short rationale: Profiles stable set-and-forget preference.

Description: Compare the temperature curve during periods of continuous proximity at session start to see whether users experience a smooth warm-up or a slow, jagged ramp, which influences perceived comfort and system quality.
short rationale: Experience quality insight with modest behavior detail.

inference: Avoidance of extreme temperatures while present
Description: Detect whether temperature excursions to very hot or very cold values mainly occur when proximity is absent, indicating that users instinctively move away from the fixture when temperature moves beyond their comfort zone.
short rationale: Shows avoidance behavior with low identifiability.

Description: Identify cases where temperature increases toward a comfort range shortly before proximity is detected, suggesting automated or scheduled preheating timed to anticipated user arrival.
short rationale: Signals anticipated arrival times and routine scheduling.

Description: Look for intervals with sustained proximity activation while temperature remains nearly flat, indicating that users are near the fixture but not interacting with temperature controls, possibly performing other tasks.
short rationale: Reveals presence and near-fixture activity without adjustments.

Description: Correlate rapid temperature drops or rises with changes in proximity; users who quickly leave or reduce presence during large temperature swings are likely reacting to thermal shock, indicating poor thermal stability.
short rationale: Captures reactions and timing to discomfort.

inference: Preferred temperature ranges when user is actively present
Description: Filter temperature data to spans where proximity is active, and derive the most common temperature ranges during presence; these ranges represent true comfort zones rather than idle or background temperatures.
short rationale: Directly infers personal comfort temperatures.

inference: Inefficient warm-up with user waiting nearby
Description: Find intervals where proximity is maintained for a long time while temperature remains far from typical comfort levels, highlighting inefficiencies where users wait unnecessarily long for water to reach the desired temperature.
short rationale: Shows wait duration and start-of-session behavior.

Description: Proximity that continues after temperature starts to decrease toward baseline suggests users linger near the fixture after turning water off, possibly enjoying residual warmth or finishing related tasks.
short rationale: Reveals post-use lingering habits and timing.

inference: Correlation between long presence and high temperature use
Description: Compare presence duration (from proximity) with average temperature during those periods; longer presence associated with higher temperatures may indicate long, hot showers or baths and potential energy-saving opportunities.
short rationale: Links long presence with hot use, profiling routine intensity.

inference: Detection of pre-use safety check behavior
Description: Proximity activation followed by short bursts of temperature adjustments without full, sustained heating suggests users are briefly checking or testing water temperature for safety (e.g., for children or sensitive skin).
short rationale: Shows cautious pre-use checks tied to safety.

Description: Relate proximity-active periods with temperature choices across seasons to reveal whether users spend more time near fixtures at higher temperatures in winter and shorter, cooler-temperature interactions in summer.
short rationale: Seasonal preference trends with coarse identifiability.

Description: Measure temperature variance only during continuous proximity intervals; high variance when users are present points to poor control and a need for better mixing or heater regulation.
short rationale: Stability metric during presence, limited behavioral detail.

inference: Detection of presence in unsafe temperature zones
Description: Identify instances when proximity indicates a user is present while temperature remains above an unsafe threshold for a sustained time, highlighting periods of elevated scalding risk.
short rationale: Shows presence during unsafe temps, strong safety/privacy signal.

Description: Short proximity intervals paired with rapid temperature increase to a moderately warm range and quick decline indicate swift warm rinses, distinct from full-length showers or extended use.
short rationale: Identifies quick-use patterns and timing.

Description: During continuous proximity, analyze the pattern of temperature changes—single large adjustments vs many small tweaks—to classify users as decisive or incremental adjusters, which can inform UI hints or presets.
short rationale: Profiles adjustment style linked to individuals.

Description: Periods where temperature remains high but proximity is absent reveal that the system is maintaining hot water when no one is nearby to use it, showing opportunities to trim idle heating based on presence patterns.
short rationale: Indicates absence with idle heating; low identity risk.

inference: Adaptive preheating based on historical presence–temperature correlation
Description: Use historical combinations of proximity timing and chosen temperatures to predict when and to what temperature to preheat the system so that water is near the desired level as soon as users next approach.
short rationale: Learns routine timing and target temps to anticipate presence.

inference: User discomfort detection via proximity interruptions
Description: Frequent break-and-return patterns in proximity aligned with periods of temperature instability suggest users are stepping away and back due to discomfort, prompting system-side improvements in thermal control.
short rationale: Shows reactions to discomfort and movement timing.

inference: Usage context inference (shower vs sink) from presence and temperature
Description: Long, continuous proximity with sustained warm temperatures likely corresponds to showers, while short, intermittent presence with modest temperatures suggests sink-based tasks.
short rationale: Infers activity type (shower vs sink) from patterns.

Description: After proximity ceases, analyze how quickly temperature drops to baseline; comparing this across fixtures gives insight into local insulation quality and whether fixtures retain heat after users leave.
short rationale: Departure timing plus cooldown; low behavioral exposure.

inference: Detection of manual vs automated temperature setting
Description: Identify whether temperature shifts during proximity are smooth and continuous (manual adjustment) or step-like and repeatable (preset or automated control), distinguishing how users interact with temperature controls.
short rationale: Shows control method preference with modest identity risk.

Description: When proximity indicates a user is present and temperature rises toward a threshold, the system can enforce dynamic limits tailored to presence patterns (e.g., stricter limits when presence suggests children vs adults).
short rationale: Uses presence context to enforce limits, exposing who/when.
